instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1398: What is A1398? A1398 is a model number for a 15 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2015, Mid 2012, Early 2013, Late 2013, Mid 2014 with EMC 2909, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00138, 820-00163, 820-00426, 820-3332, 820-3662, 820-3787..
definitions.820-3332: What is 820-3332? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.PPVCORE_S0_CPU: What is PPVCORE_S0_CPU? This is the primary power rail for the CPU that powers the CPU, known as CPU vcore. Without this, the machine will be braindead. .
definitions.PP1V05_S0:
What is PP1V05_S0? The PP1V05_S0 power rail is for various components on the logic board that require a 1.05V supply voltage in the S0 (on) state. This voltage rail is likely to be used by the CPU (for VCCIO), PCH (Platform Controller Hub).

.
definitions.PP1V5_S0: What is PP1V5_S0? PP1V5_S0 is a 1.5v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state.
definitions.PPVCORE_GPU: What is PPVCORE_GPU? This is the main power rail for the GPU. This is required for the GPU to turn on so you can get image on the display. .
definitions.PP1V8_S0: What is PP1V8_S0? PP1V8_S0 is a power rail that is present when the machine is in an S0 state, meaning it is fully turned on, not sleeping or hiberating .
definitions.PPVCORE_S0_AXG: What is PPVCORE_S0_AXG? This is vcore going to the CPU’s integrated graphics processor for CPUs that have an integrated GPU. When this is missing on a device that has an integrated GPU and no discrete GPU, it usually means either no screen is detected, or the GPU integrated into the CPU is dead..
definitions.U8900: What is U8900? This chip creates the GPU power rails on the 820-3332 board to the 2012 and early 2013 15” Retina Macbook Pros. It becomes desoldered and is the cause of no video and kernel panics/crashes in that model most of the time..
definitions.A1502: What is A1502? A1502 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2014, Late 2013, Early 2015 with EMC 2875, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-3476, 820-3536, 820-4924..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A MacBook Pro Retina 15" <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> No display 3 Beeps
threads.message:
Hi everyone,
I have this MacBook Pro for repair board <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
Got it with 3 beeps issue have tired reflow ram replace PCH no luck I decide to replace CPU because it was getting crazy warm. 
After replacement (I remove same CPU from Donner board) with was liquid damage but I was getting a display but it was too badly corroded to fix and many things doesn't work properly. 
After CPU swap laptop is turning on with no beeps but there is no display no chime fan is spinning I measure board and no power on a main rails..
There was no liquid damage on board with 3 beeps.
I have thinking maybe CPU is not connected properly but I bit worried with next soldering attempt it will die as to many times heated up.
I tried also turn on laptop on SMC bypass and all missing rails have a right voltage only <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_AXG2_L</SIGNAL> & <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_AXG1_L</SIGNAL> are not present. 
Any ideas ? Is any chance that something else could cause this issue. 
<SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0</SIGNAL> 1.05V ok

<SIGNAL>PP1V5_S0</SIGNAL> 1.52V ok

<SIGNAL>PP1V8_S0</SIGNAL> 1.81V ok

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> 3.34V ok

<SIGNAL>PPVCORE_GPU</SIGNAL> missing

<SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_CPU</SIGNAL>  missing

<SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_AXG</SIGNAL>  missing

<SIGNAL>PP1V5_S3RS0_CPUDDR</SIGNAL> 1.34V ok
PP1V5R1V35_S0GPU missing
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0GPU</SIGNAL>  missing
<SIGNAL>PP1V0_S0GPU_ISNS</SIGNAL>  missing
PPCPUVCCIO_S0_REG_R 1.01V 
<SIGNAL>VCCSAS0_LL</SIGNAL> 0,94V
<SIGNAL>GPUFB_LL</SIGNAL> 0V missing 
<SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_CPU_PH1</SIGNAL> missing 
<SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_CPU_PH2</SIGNAL> missing
<SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_CPU_PH3</SIGNAL> missing 
<SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_AXG2_L</SIGNAL> missing 
<SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_AXG1_L</SIGNAL> missing

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A MacBook Pro Retina 15" <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> No display 3 Beeps
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>PPVCORE_GPU</SIGNAL> missing"
Did you reflow <CHIP>U8900</CHIP>?
Post its volatges, if still nothing after reflow; yoy may need to change it.

"<SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_AXG2_L</SIGNAL> & <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_AXG1_L</SIGNAL>"
This voltage only appears when you open youtube, or other high graphics load on iGPU...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A MacBook Pro Retina 15" <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> No display 3 Beeps
threads.message: This sounds like trash no offense. Would not be surprised if internal traces are busted

threads.message:
Thanks for response.

I do tried reflow and replace <CHIP>U8900</CHIP> prior CPU replacement, voltages bellow. I didn't reflow or replace it after CPU replacement. 

JohnB8812 those CPU are that sensitive for temperature? Sorry for silly questions but never replace those Intel CPU's before so don't have too much experience with it. I have replace twice on <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> and there was no issues, also many GPU & PCH previously.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A MacBook Pro Retina 15" <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> No display 3 Beeps
threads.message:
Is probably waste of time.
You can check at least diode mode readings on all PCI-E caps (C80xx) from page 71.
The caps are divided in pairs and you should get same value on any pair.
And normally two different values between pairs.
